modules.title: 15.1 localStorage for Persistent Data
modules.content:
The localStorage object allows developers to store data on the client's device persistently (data remains even after the browser is closed).

Key Methods:

  • setItem(key, value): Stores the data.
  • getItem(key): Retrieves the data.
  • removeItem(key): Deletes a specific item.
modules.sample: localStorage.setItem('theme', 'dark'); let theme = localStorage.getItem('theme');

modules.title: 15.2 sessionStorage for Session Data
modules.content: Similar to localStorage, but data is only persisted for the duration of the current session. When the browser tab/window is closed, the data is cleared.
modules.sample: sessionStorage.setItem('user_session_id', 'temp-xyz-123');

modules.title: 15.3 Storing Complex Data (JSON)
modules.content: Storage APIs only handle strings. To store objects or arrays, they must first be converted to a JSON string using JSON.stringify(), and then parsed back using JSON.parse() upon retrieval.

modules.title: 15.4 IndexedDB: The Client-Side Database
modules.content: IndexedDB is a low-level API for client-side storage of large amounts of structured data, including files/blobs. It is asynchronous and transaction-based, making it suitable for complex offline applications.
modules.sample: // IndexedDB is complex and uses promises/callbacks. The core concept is opening a database: let request = window.indexedDB.open('MyDatabase', 1);

modules.title: 15.5 Introduction to Service Workers
modules.content: Service Workers are JavaScript files that run in the background, separate from the main web page. They act as a programmable network proxy, enabling offline capabilities, resource caching, and push notifications.

modules.title: 15.6 Caching Assets with the Cache API
modules.content: The Cache API, accessible from within a Service Worker, is used to store network responses (HTML, CSS, images, etc.) for offline access. It uses the caches interface.

modules.title: 15.7 Handling Cache Updates
modules.content: To update cached assets, a new Service Worker version must be installed. This involves changing the cache name (e.g., from 'v1' to 'v2') and then deleting the old cache during the activate event.

modules.title: 15.8 The Cache-First Strategy
modules.content: The 'Cache-First' strategy is a common Service Worker pattern: intercept the network request, try to find the resource in the cache first, and only fall back to the network if it's not found.

modules.title: 15.9 Detecting Network Status (Online/Offline)
modules.content: The navigator.onLine property returns a boolean indicating the browser's current network state. This is useful for displaying warnings or queuing actions.
modules.sample: if (navigator.onLine) { console.log('Connected!'); } else { console.log('Offline mode.'); }

modules.title: 15.10 Responding to Connectivity Changes
modules.content: The browser fires online and offline events on the window object, allowing you to react dynamically when the user's connection status changes.
modules.sample: window.addEventListener('online', () => { alert('You are back online!'); }); window.addEventListener('offline', () => { alert('Connection lost.'); });

modules.title: Did You Know? Storage Limits
modules.content: While IndexedDB and Cache API offer large storage (up to 50MB-500MB depending on the device and free space), localStorage is strictly limited, usually to 5MB or less per origin.

modules.title: Did You Know? Synchronous vs. Asynchronous
modules.content: Unlike localStorage and sessionStorage which are synchronous (blocking), the modern IndexedDB and Cache APIs are asynchronous, ensuring the main thread is not blocked, leading to better performance.

modules.title: 16.1 Using the **<picture>** Element
modules.content: The <picture> element is a container used to provide multiple sources for an image, allowing the browser to choose the most appropriate one based on screen size, device resolution, or image format support.
modules.sample: <picture> <source media="(min-width: 650px)" srcset="large.jpg"> <source media="(min-width: 465px)" srcset="medium.jpg"> <img src="small.jpg" alt="Description"> </picture>

modules.title: 16.2 **<source>** for Different Formats (WebP, JPEG)
modules.content: The <source> tag within <picture> can use the type attribute to offer modern, optimized image formats (like WebP) with a fallback to older formats (like JPEG) for unsupported browsers.
modules.sample: <picture> <source srcset="image.webp" type="image/webp"> <img src="image.jpeg" alt="Description"> </picture>

modules.title: 16.3 The **<track>** Element for Subtitles
modules.content: The <track> element is placed inside <video> or <audio> to provide timed text tracks, such as subtitles, captions, descriptions, or chapter titles, using the WebVTT format.
modules.sample: <video controls> <source src="video.mp4" type="video/mp4"> <track kind="captions" src="captions.vtt" srclang="en" label="English" default> </video>

modules.title: 16.4 Preload Attributes for Performance
modules.content: The preload attribute on <audio> and <video> suggests how the browser should pre-fetch the media file. Options include none (recommended), metadata, and auto.
modules.sample: <video src="video.mp4" preload="metadata" />

modules.title: 16.5 The **playsinline** Attribute
modules.content: Used primarily on iOS Safari, the boolean playsinline attribute prevents a video from automatically entering fullscreen mode when playback begins, allowing it to play inline within the page layout.
modules.sample: <video src="video.mp4" autoplay muted playsinline />

modules.title: 16.6 Introduction to Media Streams (WebRTC)
modules.content: The Media Streams API (part of WebRTC) allows you to access a user's local camera and microphone input using navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia(). The resulting stream can be displayed in a <video> element.
modules.sample: navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia({ video: true }) .then(stream => { document.getElementById('video').srcObject = stream; });

modules.title: 16.7 Custom Playback Controls with JavaScript
modules.content: By removing the controls attribute, you can hide the browser's native UI and implement custom controls using JavaScript methods like .play(), .pause(), and reading properties like .currentTime.
modules.sample: <button onclick="myVideo.play()">Play</button> <video id="myVideo" src="v.mp4"></video>

modules.title: 16.8 Media Events (canplaythrough, ended)
modules.content: Media elements fire many events. canplaythrough fires when the browser estimates it can play the media to the end without stopping for buffering. ended fires when playback finishes.
modules.sample: let video = document.getElementById('v'); video.addEventListener('ended', () => { console.log('Video finished'); });

modules.title: 16.9 Picture-in-Picture API
modules.content: The Picture-in-Picture API allows a video element to float on top of other windows/applications, even when the user navigates away from the browser tab. This is controlled via JavaScript and requires user interaction to initiate.
modules.sample: let video = document.getElementById('v'); video.requestPictureInPicture();

modules.title: 16.10 Fullscreen API
modules.content: The Fullscreen API allows an element (like a video or a whole page container) to be displayed full screen. The method requestFullscreen() is called on the element you wish to expand.
modules.sample: let el = document.documentElement; // Whole page el.requestFullscreen();

modules.title: Did You Know? The **poster** Attribute
modules.content: The poster attribute on the <video> element allows you to specify a static image to display while the video is downloading or until the user clicks the play button. This improves the initial load experience.

modules.title: Did You Know? Default Audio Controls
modules.content: Unlike <video>, the <audio> element does not display any controls (like a play button or volume slider) unless the boolean controls attribute is explicitly included.

modules.title: 17.1 The **draggable** Attribute
modules.content: The global boolean draggable attribute must be set to true on an element to make it eligible to be dragged by the user using the native HTML Drag and Drop API.
modules.sample: <div draggable="true" /> <p draggable="true">Drag me</p>

modules.title: 17.2 Drag Events: **dragstart** and **dragend**
modules.content: The dragstart event fires when the user begins dragging the element. The dragend event fires when the user releases the mouse button, regardless of a successful drop.
modules.sample: el.addEventListener('dragstart', event => { console.log('Drag started'); });

modules.title: 17.3 The **dataTransfer** Object (setData)
modules.content: The dataTransfer property of the drag event holds the data being dragged. The setData(format, data) method is used in the dragstart handler to store data.
modules.sample: el.addEventListener('dragstart', event => { event.dataTransfer.setData('text/plain', 'dragged_item_id_123'); });

modules.title: 17.4 Making a Drop Target (**dragover**)
modules.content: To make an element a valid drop target, you must prevent the browser's default handling of the dragover event by calling event.preventDefault(). This is typically done in the drop zone's dragover handler.
modules.sample: dropzone.addEventListener('dragover', event => { event.preventDefault(); });

modules.title: 17.5 Handling the Drop Event (**drop**)
modules.content: The drop event fires when the draggable element is successfully released over a valid drop target. The dragged data is retrieved using dataTransfer.getData(format).
modules.sample: dropzone.addEventListener('drop', event => { event.preventDefault(); let data = event.dataTransfer.getData('text/plain'); console.log(data); });

modules.title: 17.6 Drag Feedback (**dragenter** and **dragleave**)
modules.content: The dragenter event fires when the dragged item enters the drop zone, and dragleave fires when it leaves. These are commonly used to apply CSS classes for visual feedback (e.g., adding a border to the drop zone).
modules.sample: dropzone.addEventListener('dragenter', () => { dropzone.classList.add('drag-active'); });

modules.title: 17.7 Setting the Drop Effect
modules.content: The dataTransfer.dropEffect property controls the visual feedback (e.g., cursor) the browser gives the user. Common values are 'copy', 'move', or 'link'. It is set in the dragenter or dragover event.
modules.sample: dropzone.addEventListener('dragover', event => { event.dataTransfer.dropEffect = 'move'; event.preventDefault(); });

modules.title: 17.8 Dragging External Files (File API)
modules.content: When dragging a file from the operating system into a drop zone, the file data can be accessed via dataTransfer.files. You must use the FileReader API to read the file contents.
modules.sample: dropzone.addEventListener('drop', event => { event.dataTransfer.files[0]; // The file object });

modules.title: 17.9 Customizing the Drag Image (setDragImage)
modules.content: The browser automatically generates a ghost image of the dragged element. You can override this by calling dataTransfer.setDragImage(element, x, y) in the dragstart event to use a different element or image.
modules.sample: el.addEventListener('dragstart', event => { let img = document.getElementById('custom_drag_icon'); event.dataTransfer.setDragImage(img, 0, 0); });

modules.title: 17.10 The **contenteditable** Attribute
modules.content: The contenteditable attribute makes any element's content editable by the user, transforming it into a rich text editing area without needing an <textarea>.
modules.sample: <h2 contenteditable="true">Edit this title</h2> <div contenteditable="true" style="border: 1px solid #ccc;"></div>

modules.title: Did You Know? Dragging Links and Images
modules.content: The browser automatically sets draggable="true" for images (<img>) and links (<a>) by default, so you only need to explicitly set the attribute for other elements like <div> or <p>.

modules.title: Did You Know? The **dir** Attribute
modules.content: The dir attribute is a global attribute that specifies the text direction for the content of an element. Values are ltr (left-to-right, default) or rtl (right-to-left), crucial for internationalization.

modules.title: 18.1 Introduction to Geolocation API
modules.content: The Geolocation API allows a web page to access a user's geographical location using navigator.geolocation. The user must explicitly grant permission for this to work, typically via a browser prompt.
modules.sample: if ('geolocation' in navigator) { navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition(successCallback, errorCallback); }

modules.title: 18.2 Retrieving the User's Position (getCurrentPosition)
modules.content: The primary method, getCurrentPosition(success, error, options), asynchronously requests a one-time location fix. The success callback receives a Position object containing the coordinates.
modules.sample: function successCallback(position) { let lat = position.coords.latitude; console.log(lat); }

modules.title: 18.3 Monitoring Position Changes (watchPosition)
modules.content: The watchPosition() method is used to continuously monitor the user's location and fires the success callback every time the user's position changes. It returns a watcher ID used to stop monitoring with clearWatch().
modules.sample: let watchID = navigator.geolocation.watchPosition(success); navigator.geolocation.clearWatch(watchID);

modules.title: 18.4 Geolocation Error Handling
modules.content: The optional second argument to getCurrentPosition() is an error callback. Common error codes include 1 (Permission Denied) and 3 (Timeout).
modules.sample: function errorCallback(error) { if (error.code == 1) { alert('Location permission denied'); } }

modules.title: 18.5 Geolocation Options (timeout, enableHighAccuracy)
modules.content: The third, optional argument to location methods is an PositionOptions object. timeout limits the time for the request, and enableHighAccuracy: true requests the best possible location data (which may take longer and consume more power).
modules.sample: navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition( success, error, { enableHighAccuracy: true, timeout: 5000 } );

modules.title: 18.6 Introduction to Notifications API
modules.content: The Notifications API allows a web page to display system-level notifications to the user, even if the tab is not currently active. Like Geolocation, it requires explicit user permission.
modules.sample: if ('Notification' in window) { console.log('Notifications supported'); }

modules.title: 18.7 Requesting Notification Permission
modules.content: Permission is requested using Notification.requestPermission(), which returns a promise that resolves to the current state: 'granted', 'denied', or 'default' (waiting for user choice).
modules.sample: Notification.requestPermission().then(permission => { console.log(permission); });

modules.title: 18.8 Creating a Simple Notification
modules.content: To create a notification, use the new Notification(title, options) constructor, passing the required title and an optional object for the body text, icon, and tag.
modules.sample: if (Notification.permission === 'granted') { let n = new Notification('New Message', { body: 'You have 1 unread email.' }); }

modules.title: 18.9 Notification Events (click, close)
modules.content: Notification objects emit events like click and close. Handling the click event is common to bring the user back to the relevant application tab.
modules.sample: let n = new Notification('Title'); n.addEventListener('click', () => { window.focus(); });

modules.title: 18.10 Permission Status Check
modules.content: The current permission status for an API can be checked using Notification.permission or the general navigator.permissions API, which avoids triggering the permission prompt until a user action warrants it.
modules.sample: if (Notification.permission === 'denied') { console.error('User blocked notifications.'); }

modules.title: Did You Know? Geolocation Accuracy
modules.content: The browser determines location using various sources in order of precision: **GPS** (most accurate, highest power), **Wi-Fi** (moderate), and **IP address** (least accurate, lowest power). Using enableHighAccuracy: true forces the use of more precise methods like GPS.

modules.title: Did You Know? Re-requesting Permission
modules.content: If a user chooses to block an API permission (e.g., location or notifications), you generally cannot programmatically trigger the permission prompt again. The user must manually change the setting in their browser preferences.

modules.title: 19.1 Introduction to WebSockets
modules.content: WebSockets provide a full-duplex, two-way communication channel over a single, long-lived TCP connection. This enables real-time data transfer without constantly polling the server, ideal for chat or games.
modules.sample: let socket = new WebSocket('ws://example.com/ws');

modules.title: 19.2 WebSocket Connection Events (**open, close**)
modules.content: The open event fires once the connection is successfully established and ready for data transfer. The close event fires when the connection has been shut down, either by the client or the server.
modules.sample: socket.addEventListener('open', () => { console.log('WebSocket connected!'); });

modules.title: 19.3 Sending Data (**send()** Method)
modules.content: Once the connection is open, the send(data) method is used to transmit data from the client to the server. The data can be a string, Blob, ArrayBuffer, or a View.
modules.sample: socket.addEventListener('open', () => { socket.send('Hello Server'); });

modules.title: 19.4 Receiving Data (**message** Event)
modules.content: The message event fires every time the client receives data from the server. The actual data is contained in the event.data property.
modules.sample: socket.addEventListener('message', event => { console.log('Received:', event.data); });

modules.title: 19.5 WebSocket State (readyState)
modules.content: The readyState property returns the current state of the WebSocket connection as a number: 0 (CONNECTING), 1 (OPEN), 2 (CLOSING), or 3 (CLOSED).
modules.sample: if (socket.readyState === 1) { socket.send('Data'); }

modules.title: 19.6 Introduction to Server-Sent Events (SSE)
modules.content: Server-Sent Events (SSE) allow a server to push one-way updates to a client over a single HTTP connection. Unlike WebSockets, SSE is unidirectional (server to client only) but simpler to implement for streams of simple data like stock tickers or news feeds.
modules.sample: let eventSource = new EventSource('/updates');

modules.title: 19.7 Handling SSE Events (**message, error**)
modules.content: The EventSource object primarily uses the message event to handle incoming data. The server sends data prefixed with data:, which is then accessible via event.data.
modules.sample: eventSource.onmessage = event => { console.log(event.data); };

modules.title: 19.8 SSE Custom Events
modules.content: Servers can send data tagged with a custom event name (prefixed with event:). On the client, you listen for this custom event name using addEventListener() instead of the generic message event.

modules.title: 19.9 WebSockets vs. SSE
modules.content: WebSockets are better for bi-directional communication (chat, gaming). SSE is better for simple, server-initiated, one-way data feeds (stock quotes, notifications) because it has lower overhead and handles auto-reconnection natively.
modules.sample: // No sample code, conceptual comparison.

modules.title: 19.10 Closing the WebSocket Connection
modules.content: The connection is closed using the close(code, reason) method, where code is a status code (e.g., 1000 for normal closure) and reason is an optional string.
modules.sample: socket.close(1000, 'Normal exit');

modules.title: Did You Know? The WebSocket Protocol
modules.content: WebSockets use a different protocol than HTTP. The connection starts as an HTTP request (a 'handshake') but then upgrades to the **ws://** (or **wss://** for secure) protocol, meaning it operates on its own persistent connection.

modules.title: Did You Know? SSE Auto-Reconnect
modules.content: One of the major advantages of Server-Sent Events is that the browser automatically attempts to reconnect to the source if the connection is dropped, without requiring any manual JavaScript code for error handling and retry logic.

modules.title: 20.1 Introduction to Web Components
modules.content: Web Components are a set of four technologies that allow developers to create reusable, encapsulated, custom HTML elements with their own functionality. The core technologies are Custom Elements, Shadow DOM, HTML Templates, and HTML Imports (now deprecated/superseded).
modules.sample: // Conceptual introduction.

modules.title: 20.2 Creating Custom Elements (v1)
modules.content: Custom Elements allow you to define a new HTML tag (e.g., <my-button>). They must be defined via a JavaScript class that extends HTMLElement and registered using customElements.define().

modules.title: 20.3 Custom Element Naming Rules
modules.content: Custom element names must contain a hyphen (e.g., <user-card>). This prevents conflicts with built-in HTML tags and ensures forward compatibility as new tags are added to the standard.

modules.title: 20.4 Lifecycle Callbacks
modules.content: Custom elements have specific methods that are called automatically at different points in their life: connectedCallback() (added to DOM), disconnectedCallback() (removed from DOM), and attributeChangedCallback().

modules.title: 20.5 Attaching the Shadow DOM (open/closed)
modules.content: The Shadow DOM provides style and markup encapsulation. It is attached to a custom element instance using attachShadow(), typically with the mode set to 'open' (accessible from outside) or 'closed' (inaccessible).

modules.title: 20.6 Encapsulation and CSS
modules.content: The Shadow DOM's primary benefit is **CSS scoping**. Styles defined within the Shadow DOM (e.g., in a <style> tag inside the shadow root) will only apply to that component's internal structure and cannot leak out to the main document.

modules.title: 20.7 The **<template>** Tag
modules.content: The <template> element is used to hold fragments of markup that are not rendered when the page loads. The content is inert and can be cloned and reused by JavaScript to populate the Shadow DOM of custom elements.
modules.sample: <template id="user-template"> <p>User Name: <slot>Default</slot></p> </template>

modules.title: 20.8 Content Insertion with **<slot>**
modules.content: The <slot> element is a placeholder inside the Shadow DOM that dictates where the light DOM (the content inside the custom element's tags) should be rendered. This allows users to inject their own content into a component's pre-defined structure.
modules.sample:
<my-card> <h3>Card Title</h3> // Light DOM content </my-card> // Shadow DOM uses to display the

content.

modules.title: 20.9 Named Slots
modules.content: By adding the name attribute to <slot>, you create specific placeholders. The light DOM content is targeted to these slots using its own slot attribute.

modules.title: 20.10 Accessibility and Web Components
modules.content: Because the Shadow DOM is mostly hidden from screen readers, proper use of WAI-ARIA attributes (like role, aria-label) on the custom element itself and within the light DOM content is crucial for maintaining accessibility.
modules.sample: <my-slider role="slider" aria-valuemax="100"></my-slider>

modules.title: Did You Know? Default HTML Elements
modules.content: Many built-in HTML elements, like <video>, <input type="range">, and <select>, internally use the concept of Shadow DOM to hide their complex internal structure (e.g., the controls on a video player).

modules.title: Did You Know? Styling Shadow Content
modules.content: While CSS is scoped in the Shadow DOM, you can create styling hooks from the outside using CSS Custom Properties (CSS Variables), allowing the main document's styles to partially influence the component's internal appearance.

modules.title: 21.1 The **<canvas>** Tag (2D/3D Graphics)
modules.content: The <canvas> element provides a drawing surface for rendering 2D shapes, complex charts, or 3D graphics (using WebGL). All drawing operations must be done via JavaScript.
modules.sample: <canvas id="myCanvas" width="400" height="200"></canvas>

modules.title: 21.2 Getting the 2D Rendering Context
modules.content: Before drawing, you must get the canvas's rendering context using getContext('2d'). This object provides all the drawing methods (lines, shapes, text, etc.).
modules.sample: let canvas = document.getElementById('myCanvas'); let ctx = canvas.getContext('2d');

modules.title: 21.3 Drawing Rectangles and Paths
modules.content: Basic shapes are drawn using methods on the context object. fillRect(x, y, w, h) draws a solid rectangle. For complex shapes, you use beginPath(), lineTo(), and stroke()/fill().

modules.title: 21.4 Drawing Text on Canvas
modules.content: Canvas supports drawing text. You set the font properties using the font property (e.g., '12px serif') and then use fillText(text, x, y) or strokeText() to render it.
modules.sample: ctx.font = '30px Arial'; ctx.fillText('Canvas Text', 10, 50);

modules.title: 21.5 Introduction to SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics)
modules.content: SVG is an XML-based markup language for describing two-dimensional vector graphics. Unlike canvas (raster), SVG graphics are resolution-independent and can be scaled indefinitely without loss of quality.
modules.sample: <svg width="100" height="100"> <circle cx="50" cy="50" r="40" fill="red"/> </svg>

modules.title: 21.6 Core SVG Shapes (**<rect>, <circle>**)
modules.content: SVG uses specific elements to define shapes. <rect> (rectangle) uses `x`, `y`, `width`, and `height`. <circle> uses `cx`, `cy` (center coordinates), and `r` (radius).
modules.sample: <rect x="10" y="10" width="80" height="30" fill="green"/>

modules.title: 21.7 Styling SVG with CSS
modules.content: SVG elements can be styled using CSS just like HTML elements. Properties like fill (background color) and stroke (border color) replace the HTML/CSS background-color and border-color properties.
modules.sample: circle { fill: #007bff; stroke: #000; stroke-width: 2px; }

modules.title: 21.8 SVG Coordinate System and **viewBox**
modules.content: The SVG coordinate system starts at (0, 0) in the top-left corner. The viewBox attribute defines the internal coordinate system of the SVG element, making the graphic scale proportionally to the containing element's dimensions (defined by `width` and `height`).
modules.sample: <svg viewBox="0 0 100 100" width="50%" />

modules.title: 21.9 Manipulating SVG with JavaScript
modules.content: Since inline SVG is part of the DOM, its elements and attributes can be fully manipulated with standard JavaScript methods like getElementById() and setAttribute(), enabling dynamic charts and interactive graphics.
modules.sample: document.getElementById('my-circle').setAttribute('fill', 'blue');

modules.title: 21.10 Canvas vs. SVG Comparison
modules.content: **Canvas** is raster-based, pixel-by-pixel rendering, best for complex, dynamic scenes (games, photos). **SVG** is vector-based, best for scalable, static, or data-driven graphics (logos, charts, icons) where DOM interaction is needed.
modules.sample: // Conceptual comparison.

modules.title: Did You Know? Canvas Accessibility
modules.content: By default, the content drawn on a <canvas> is invisible to screen readers. To fix this, you should provide alternative descriptive content *between* the opening and closing <canvas> tags, or use ARIA attributes that JavaScript updates.

modules.title: Did You Know? SVG Filters
modules.content: SVG supports a dedicated system for creating complex graphical effects using the <filter> element and its primitives (like <feGaussianBlur>). These effects can be applied to both SVG and HTML elements.

modules.title: 22.1 Script Loading: **async** vs. **defer**
modules.content:
The async and defer attributes on the <script> tag control how external JavaScript files are downloaded and executed without blocking HTML parsing.

Key Differences:

  • async: Downloads in parallel, executes as soon as it finishes (may interrupt parsing).
  • defer: Downloads in parallel, executes in order *after* HTML parsing is complete.
modules.sample: <script src="lib.js" async></script> <script src="app.js" defer></script>

modules.title: 22.2 Resource Hints: **rel='preload'**
modules.content: The <link rel="preload"> tag tells the browser to aggressively fetch a resource (CSS, font, script) and store it in the local cache, but *without* executing it. This is used for critical resources needed very soon.
modules.sample: <link rel="preload" href="/fonts/myfont.woff2" as="font" crossorigin>

modules.title: 22.3 Resource Hints: **rel='prefetch'**
modules.content: The rel="prefetch" hint tells the browser to fetch a resource that will *likely* be needed for a future navigation (e.g., the next page in a sequence). It is a low-priority download performed during browser idle time.
modules.sample: <link rel="prefetch" href="/next-page/style.css" >

modules.title: 22.4 Connection Hints: **rel='preconnect'**
modules.content: The rel="preconnect" hint instructs the browser to initiate an early connection (DNS lookup, TCP handshake, TLS negotiation) to a third-party origin. This eliminates connection latency when the resource is finally requested.
modules.sample: <link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.gstatic.com">

modules.title: 22.5 Image Lazy Loading with **loading='lazy'**
modules.content: The loading="lazy" attribute on <img> and <iframe> defers loading of the resource until it is within a calculated distance of the user's viewport, saving bandwidth and improving initial load time.
modules.sample: <img src="large-image.jpg" loading="lazy" />

modules.title: 22.6 The **importance** Attribute (Priority Hint)
modules.content: The importance attribute on tags like <img> or <link> provides a hint to the browser about the resource's download priority. Values are 'high', 'low', or 'auto', helping the browser prioritize fetching.
modules.sample: <img src="hero.jpg" importance="high" />

modules.title: 22.7 Image Decoding Hint (**decoding**)
modules.content: The decoding attribute suggests to the browser how an image should be decoded: 'sync' (in parallel with the content) or 'async' (without blocking rendering). Setting it to 'async' is recommended for large, non-critical images.
modules.sample: <img src="background.jpg" decoding="async" />

modules.title: 22.8 **referrerpolicy** Attribute for Security
modules.content: The global referrerpolicy attribute controls how much referrer information (the page the user came from) is sent in the HTTP request header when navigating to a new link, fetching an image, or loading a script. Common values include 'no-referrer' and 'strict-origin-when-cross-origin'.
modules.sample: <a href="/ext.html" referrerpolicy="no-referrer">Link</a>

modules.title: 22.9 **crossorigin** Attribute for CORS
modules.content: The crossorigin attribute on <script>, <link>, and <img> tags configures the CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) request for fetching resources from a different domain. It's essential when manipulating cross-origin data (e.g., drawing a cross-origin image on a canvas).
modules.sample: <img src="https://cdn.com/img.jpg" crossorigin="anonymous" />

modules.title: 22.10 The **inert** Attribute for Accessibility
modules.content: The boolean inert attribute makes an element and all its descendant elements completely unreachable to the user. This means it cannot be focused (via keyboard/tab) and is ignored by screen readers. It's ideal for non-modal background content when a modal dialog is open.
modules.sample: <div inert> <button>(Cannot be focused)</button> </div>

modules.title: Did You Know? Blocking vs. Non-Blocking Scripts
modules.content: A <script> tag without async or defer is a **parser-blocking** resource. When the browser hits it, it must stop parsing the HTML, download the script, execute it, and only then continue parsing the rest of the document, leading to slower page rendering.

modules.title: Did You Know? DNS Pre-resolution
modules.content: Another common connection hint is rel="dns-prefetch", which performs only the DNS lookup for a domain. It is less aggressive than preconnect but can still save a few milliseconds of latency.

modules.title: 23.1 The **<time>** Element and datetime Attribute
modules.content: The <time> element is used to display human-readable dates or times while providing a machine-readable value in the datetime attribute. This improves semantics for search engines and accessibility tools.
modules.sample: <p>The event starts at <time datetime="2025-10-26T14:30Z">2:30 PM, October 26th, 2025</time> </p>

modules.title: 23.2 The **<mark>** Element
modules.content: The <mark> element is used to highlight or mark text that is of particular relevance in the context of a document, often rendered with a yellow background. Unlike <strong>, it denotes relevance, not importance.
modules.sample: <p>Search results show the closest match for <mark>HTML</mark> tags.</p>

modules.title: 23.3 The **<output>** Element
modules.content: The <output> element is used to display the result of a calculation or a user action (e.g., from a form script). It can be linked to the inputs used for the calculation via the for attribute.
modules.sample: <form oninput="result.value = a.valueAsNumber + b.valueAsNumber"> <input type="number" id="a" /> + <output name="result" for="a b">0</output> </form>

modules.title: 23.4 The **<wbr>** Tag (Word Break Opportunity)
modules.content: The <wbr> (Word Break Opportunity) tag tells the browser *where* a word may be safely broken into two lines if the space is insufficient, helping prevent horizontal overflow on very long, unbroken strings (like URLs or technical terms).
modules.sample: <p>The long word is: supercalifragilistic<wbr>expialidocious</p>

modules.title: 23.5 The **<data>** Element and value Attribute
modules.content: The <data> element is similar to <time>, used to link human-readable content to a machine-readable data value. It is primarily used for non-date/time values like product IDs or SKUs.
modules.sample: <ul> <li>Product: <data value="SKU345">Red Shirt</data></li> </ul>

modules.title: 23.6 Microdata Introduction (itemscope, itemtype, itemprop)
modules.content: Microdata is a form of structured data used to embed semantics into HTML content, making it machine-readable for search engines. It uses the attributes itemscope (defines an item), itemtype (defines the type, e.g., 'Person'), and itemprop (defines a property, e.g., 'name').
modules.sample: <div itemscope itemtype="https://schema.org/Person"> My name is <span itemprop="name">John Doe</span> </div>

modules.title: 23.7 The **<bdi>** Tag (Bi-Directional Isolation)
modules.content: The <bdi> element isolates a piece of text that might be formatted in a different text direction (e.g., right-to-left usernames in a left-to-right document) from the surrounding text, preventing potential display corruption.
modules.sample: <ul>\n <li>User: <bdi>Leo\_rtl\_user</bdi> - 12 points</li>\n</ul>

modules.title: 23.8 The **<dfn>** Tag (Definition Term)
modules.content: The <dfn> element is used to denote the defining instance of a term within the surrounding content. It helps establish the semantic context of a specialized word or phrase.
modules.sample: <p>A <dfn>Web Component</dfn> is a reusable piece of code.</p>

modules.title: 23.9 The **<sitemap>** Element (Fictional/Conceptual)
modules.content: While not a standard HTML tag, many developers conceptually link the page's structure to a sitemap.xml file via the <link> tag. A sitemap is a list of a website's URLs, informing search engines about the available pages for crawling.
modules.sample: <link rel="sitemap" type="application/xml" href="/sitemap.xml">

modules.title: 23.10 The **role** Attribute (ARIA)
modules.content: The role attribute (part of WAI-ARIA) is used to explicitly define the purpose or type of an element for assistive technologies, especially when using non-semantic tags like <div> for a complex UI widget.
modules.sample: <div id="alert-box" role="alert">Access Denied</div>

modules.title: Did You Know? The `abbr` Attribute on <time>
modules.content: When a <time> element only contains a date (like '2025-10-26'), you can omit the datetime attribute. However, if you are providing a full machine-readable time, the datetime attribute should follow the ISO 8601 standard for unambiguous parsing.

modules.title: Did You Know? Default ARIA Roles
modules.content: Many semantic HTML5 elements already have an implicit ARIA role. For example, <nav> implicitly has role="navigation", and <button> has role="button". Always use the native semantic tag over ARIA roles on generic <div>s if possible.

modules.title: 24.1 Client-Side Debugging (**console** Methods)
modules.content: The console object provides methods beyond .log() for better debugging. This includes .warn() (yellow text), .error() (red text/stack trace), and .info().
modules.sample: console.error('Failed to load resource.'); console.warn('Using deprecated function.');

modules.title: 24.2 Console Debugging (**dir, table**)
modules.content: The console.dir(object) method displays an interactive list of the properties of the specified JavaScript object. .table(array) displays an array of objects as a sortable table.
modules.sample: let data = [{id:1}, {id:2}]; console.table(data);

modules.title: 24.3 Measuring Time (**time, timeEnd**)
modules.content: You can measure the execution time of JavaScript code blocks using console.time(label) and console.timeEnd(label). The time difference is output to the console.
modules.sample: console.time('fetch-time'); // ... Code to measure ... console.timeEnd('fetch-time');

modules.title: 24.4 Assertions (**assert** Method)
modules.content: The console.assert(condition, message) method checks a condition. If the condition is false, it logs an error message to the console without halting script execution. This is useful for pre-conditions and parameter checks.
modules.sample: let val = 5; console.assert(val === 10, 'Value is not 10');

modules.title: 24.5 Profiling Code (**profile, profileEnd**)
modules.content: The console.profile(name) and .profileEnd(name) methods initiate and stop a CPU usage profile. The results are viewable in the browser's developer tools 'Performance' tab, showing function call times and resource consumption.
modules.sample: console.profile('draw-chart'); // ... Chart drawing code ... console.profileEnd('draw-chart');

modules.title: 24.6 Debugging DOM Changes (Breakpoints)
modules.content: Browser DevTools allow setting breakpoints directly on DOM elements. You can pause JavaScript execution when an element's attributes change, its sub-tree is modified, or the element is removed, which is invaluable for debugging complex UI libraries.
modules.sample: // No code sample, action performed in DevTools (Right-click element -> Break on...)

modules.title: 24.7 Network Throttling in DevTools
modules.content: The Network tab in DevTools allows you to simulate slower network conditions (like 'Fast 3G' or 'Slow 3G'). This helps you diagnose performance issues related to asset loading times and responsiveness under poor network conditions.
modules.sample: // No code sample, action performed in DevTools (Network tab -> Throttling dropdown).

modules.title: 24.8 Security Headers Check (CSP)
modules.content: The Network tab also displays HTTP response headers. You should check for proper security headers like **Content-Security-Policy (CSP)**, which helps prevent XSS attacks, and **Strict-Transport-Security (HSTS)**, which forces HTTPS connections.
modules.sample: // Conceptual: Looking for response headers in the Network tab.

modules.title: 24.9 The **debugger** Keyword
modules.content: Inserting the JavaScript debugger keyword directly into your code will automatically pause execution at that line if the browser's developer tools are open, acting as a programmatic breakpoint.
modules.sample: function calculate(val) { debugger; // Execution pauses here return val * 2; }

modules.title: 24.10 Error Reporting: **window.onerror**
modules.content: The window.onerror handler captures uncaught JavaScript errors, providing the error message, URL, line number, and column number. This is crucial for logging client-side errors to a server for monitoring.
modules.sample: window.onerror = function(message, url, line) { console.log('Error caught: ' + message); return true; // Prevent default browser handling };

modules.title: Did You Know? Console Groups
modules.content: You can organize console output into collapsible sections using console.group(label) and console.groupEnd(). This keeps verbose logging neat and manageable.

modules.title: Did You Know? Network Waterfall Chart
modules.content: The Network tab displays a 'waterfall' chart, which is a visual representation of how long each resource (HTML, CSS, JS, images) took for DNS lookup, connection, sending, waiting, and receiving, helping pinpoint bottlenecks.

modules.title: 25.1 CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) Policy
modules.content: CORS is a mechanism that uses HTTP headers to allow a server to indicate any origins (domains, protocols, ports) other than its own from which a browser should permit loading resources. It prevents simple cross-site requests by default for security.
modules.sample: // Conceptual introduction. Controlled via server headers: Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *

modules.title: 25.2 The **<meta>** Tag for X-UA-Compatible
modules.content: The <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge"> tag forced older versions of Internet Explorer (IE) to render the page using the highest available document mode, preventing compatibility mode issues. It is obsolete in modern browsers.
modules.sample: <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge">

modules.title: 25.3 Content Security Policy (CSP) Directives
modules.content: CSP is a critical security layer that helps mitigate attacks like XSS by restricting the sources of content (scripts, styles, images) that can be loaded on a page. Directives like script-src and default-src define allowed sources.
modules.sample: <meta http-equiv="Content-Security-Policy" content="default-src 'self'; script-src 'self' cdn.com;">

modules.title: 25.4 The **sandbox** Attribute on **<iframe\>**
modules.content: The boolean sandbox attribute on an <iframe> applies severe security restrictions to the content, preventing common activities like script execution, form submission, and pointer locking by default, thereby isolating untrusted content.
modules.sample: <iframe src="untrusted.html" sandbox ></iframe>

modules.title: 25.5 Allowing Exceptions in Sandbox (**allow-** directives)
modules.content: To lift specific restrictions while using sandbox, you add tokens like allow-scripts, allow-forms, or allow-same-origin as the attribute value. Only necessary permissions should be granted.
modules.sample: <iframe src="safe-script.html" sandbox="allow-scripts allow-same-origin" ></iframe>

modules.title: 25.6 The **csp** Attribute on **<iframe\>**
modules.content: The csp attribute allows you to apply a Content Security Policy directly to the embedded content within a sandboxed <iframe>, providing a granular level of control over what the nested page can load/do.
modules.sample: <iframe sandbox csp="default-src 'none'; media-src 'self'" ></iframe>

modules.title: 25.7 XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) Prevention
modules.content: The core defense against XSS is sanitizing and escaping all user input before rendering it to the DOM. Never insert raw, unvalidated input into `element.innerHTML`. Also, proper use of CSP prevents external scripts from being injected.

modules.title: 25.8 CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) Protection
modules.content: CSRF is an attack where an attacker tricks a victim's browser into sending a malicious request to a trusted site. HTML itself does not prevent this, but the browser's SameSite cookie attribute and server-side anti-CSRF tokens are the primary defenses.
modules.sample: // Conceptual: Protection relies on server-side tokens and cookie security.

modules.title: 25.9 Setting the Favicon
modules.content: The favicon (the small icon in the browser tab) is set using a <link> tag in the <head>, specifying the icon file and MIME type. Using the sizes attribute helps the browser pick the correct resolution for the device.
modules.sample: <link rel="icon" href="/favicon.ico" /> <link rel="icon" type="image/png" sizes="32x32" href="/icon-32.png" />

modules.title: 25.10 Apple Touch Icons and Manifest
modules.content: For Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) and mobile home screen icons, specific link tags are required: rel="apple-touch-icon" for iOS, and a <link rel="manifest"> for a JSON file that defines the app's metadata.
modules.sample: <link rel="apple-touch-icon" href="/touch-icon.png" /> <link rel="manifest" href="/manifest.json" />

modules.title: Did You Know? Cookie Security Flags
modules.content: Cookies can be secured by setting the Secure flag (only sent over HTTPS), the HttpOnly flag (prevents JavaScript access to the cookie), and the SameSite flag (prevents cross-site request attacks).

modules.title: Did You Know? Preflight Requests
modules.content: Before a browser performs a complex cross-origin request (e.g., using a non-standard HTTP method or custom headers), it often sends a 'preflight' request using the HTTP **OPTIONS** method. This allows the server to verify the request's safety via CORS headers before the actual request is sent.

modules.title: 26.1 Introduction to WebGL (3D Graphics)
modules.content: WebGL is a JavaScript API for rendering high-performance interactive 2D and 3D graphics within any compatible web browser without the need for plug-ins. It is based on the OpenGL ES standard and uses the <canvas> element.
modules.sample: let canvas = document.getElementById('webgl-canvas'); let gl = canvas.getContext('webgl'); if (!gl) { alert('WebGL not supported.'); }

modules.title: 26.2 Shaders: Vertex and Fragment
modules.content: WebGL rendering relies on shaders, small programs written in GLSL (OpenGL Shading Language). The **Vertex Shader** determines the position of 3D vertices, and the **Fragment Shader** calculates the color for every pixel/fragment being drawn.
modules.sample: // Conceptual: Shaders are complex strings of GLSL code.

modules.title: 26.3 The Web Workers API (Multithreading)
modules.content: Web Workers run scripts in background threads separate from the main execution thread. This prevents long-running or computationally expensive tasks from blocking the UI, improving responsiveness. Communication is done via `postMessage()`.

modules.title: 26.4 Transferable Objects in Workers
modules.content: Transferable Objects (like ArrayBuffer) can be transferred from one thread to another without expensive copying. This drastically speeds up passing large binary data (e.g., image buffers or large arrays) between the main thread and a Web Worker.
modules.sample: let buffer = new ArrayBuffer(1024); worker.postMessage({ buffer: buffer }, [ buffer ]);

modules.title: 26.5 The **<map>** and **<area>** Tags
modules.content: The <map> element creates a client-side image map that is linked to an <img> via the usemap attribute. The <area> tags within the map define clickable, invisible regions on the image with different links/actions.
modules.sample: <img src="map.jpg" usemap="#productmap" /> <map name="productmap"> <area shape="rect" coords="0,0,82,126" href="/area1.html"/> </map>

modules.title: 26.6 The **<abbr>** Tag (Abbreviation)
modules.content: The <abbr> element is used to denote an abbreviation or acronym. The full meaning is provided in the title attribute, which improves accessibility and provides tooltips on hover.
modules.sample: <p>The <abbr title="HyperText Markup Language">HTML</abbr> is essential.</p>

modules.title: 26.7 The **<cite>** Tag (Title of Work)
modules.content: The <cite> element is used to denote the title of a work (e.g., a book, song, film, sculpture, or painting). Browsers typically render the content in italics.
modules.sample: <p>My favorite book is <cite>Moby Dick</cite>.</p>

modules.title: 26.8 The **<var>** Tag (Variable Name)
modules.content: The <var> element is used to indicate a variable in a computer program or a mathematical expression. This provides semantic meaning and is often rendered in italics by the browser.
modules.sample: <p>The user's ID is stored in the <var>userId</var> variable.</p>

modules.title: 26.9 The **<noscript>** Tag
modules.content: The <noscript> element provides an alternative content block to be displayed to users who have disabled JavaScript in their browser or whose browser does not support scripting. It is mainly used for backwards compatibility or warnings.
modules.sample: <noscript> <p>Please enable JavaScript to view this page.</p> </noscript>

modules.title: 26.10 The **<rp>** and **<rt>** Tags (Ruby Annotation)
modules.content: The <rp> (Ruby Parentheses) and <rt> (Ruby Text) elements are used in conjunction with <ruby> to provide pronunciation or annotation for East Asian characters.
modules.sample: <ruby> <rp>(</rp><rt>Han</rt><rp>)</rp> </ruby>

modules.title: Did You Know? WebGL Frameworks
modules.content: Directly working with the raw WebGL API is very complex. Most modern web developers use high-level, production-ready libraries built on top of WebGL, such as **Three.js** or **Babylon.js**, to simplify 3D scene creation, lighting, and camera control.

modules.title: Did You Know? The Worker Global Scope
modules.content: Web Workers operate in a separate global scope that does *not* have access to the main page's DOM (Document Object Model). This is a security and performance measure to prevent long-running tasks from manipulating the visible UI.

modules.title: 27.1 The **tabindex** Attribute
modules.content: The global tabindex attribute controls whether an element can receive keyboard focus and where it participates in sequential keyboard navigation (tabbing). Values: -1 (focusable, but not in tab order), 0 (default tab order), and positive numbers (explicit tab order).
modules.sample: <div tabindex="0">Focusable Content</div> <button tabindex="-1">Hidden from tab</button>

modules.title: 27.2 ARIA States and Properties (**aria-** attributes)
modules.content: WAI-ARIA provides attributes (prefixed with aria-) that define states (e.g., aria-expanded, aria-checked) and properties (e.g., aria-labelledby, aria-live) for dynamic content, ensuring screen readers announce changes correctly.
modules.sample: <button aria-expanded="false">Toggle Menu</button> <div aria-live="polite">New Content Arrives Here</div>

modules.title: 27.3 Live Regions (**aria-live**)
modules.content: Live regions (defined by aria-live="polite" or aria-live="assertive") tell assistive technology to monitor the element for content changes and announce them to the user without interrupting their current task. Used for notifications, status messages, and dynamic updates.
modules.sample: <div role="status" aria-live="polite">Form submission successful.</div>

modules.title: 27.4 The **aria-label** Attribute
modules.content: The aria-label attribute provides a visible text label for an element when no visible label exists. It is critical for icon-only buttons or interactive elements that have no discernible name for screen reader users.
modules.sample: <button aria-label="Close Modal">X</button>

modules.title: 27.5 The **aria-labelledby** and **aria-describedby** Attributes
modules.content: aria-labelledby links an element to another element's ID to use its content as a label. aria-describedby links to text that provides a longer, optional description (like tooltips or validation errors).
modules.sample: <h2 id="m-id">Modal Title</h2> <div role="dialog" aria-labelledby="m-id"></div>

modules.title: 27.6 Responsive Design with **<meta>** Viewport
modules.content: The viewport <meta> tag is essential for responsive web design. width=device-width sets the viewport width to the screen width, and initial-scale=1.0 prevents the page from being zoomed out by default.
modules.sample: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">

modules.title: 27.7 Preventing Zooming on Mobile (Accessibility concern)
modules.content: Setting user-scalable=no or maximum-scale=1.0 in the viewport meta tag prevents users from zooming. This is generally discouraged for accessibility reasons, as it denies low-vision users the ability to magnify text.
modules.sample: // Discouraged but demonstrates the control: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0, maximum-scale=1.0, user-scalable=no">

modules.title: 27.8 HTML for Print (media='print')
modules.content: You can define specific CSS rules for printing the document by linking a separate stylesheet using the media="print" attribute on the <link> tag. This is used to hide navigation, remove backgrounds, and optimize font size for paper.
modules.sample: <link rel="stylesheet" href="/print.css" media="print">

modules.title: 27.9 The **hidden** Attribute
modules.content: The boolean global hidden attribute prevents an element from being displayed. It is semantically preferable to display: none in CSS, as it clearly communicates that the element is not yet, or no longer, relevant.
modules.sample: <div id="loader">Loading...</div> <div id="content" hidden>Loaded Content</div>

modules.title: 27.10 The **dir** Attribute (Advanced use)
modules.content: Using the dir="rtl" (right-to-left) attribute on the entire <html> element correctly configures the browser layout for languages like Arabic or Hebrew, ensuring proper alignment of text, lists, and form elements.
modules.sample: <html lang="ar" dir="rtl"> ... </html>

modules.title: Did You Know? The **:focus-visible** CSS Selector
modules.content: A common accessibility improvement is the use of the :focus-visible CSS pseudoclass. This selector only applies a focus ring (outline) when the element is focused via the keyboard (tabbing), but not when clicked with the mouse, improving visual aesthetics without sacrificing accessibility.

modules.title: Did You Know? Default Tab Order
modules.content: The default tab order (when tabindex is not explicitly set) is determined by the element's position in the source HTML document. Semantic elements like links, buttons, and form controls are naturally included in this flow.

quiz.question: Setting tabindex='-1' on an element allows it to be focused by JavaScript but prevents it from:
options: Being part of the sequential keyboard tab order
quiz.answer: Being part of the sequential keyboard tab order

modules.title: 28.1 The **<dialog>** Element (Modal/Non-Modal)
modules.content: The <dialog> element provides a native, semantic way to create a modal or non-modal popup window. When displayed modally, it automatically handles the overlay and focus management.
modules.sample: <dialog id="my-dialog"> <p>This is a modal window.</p> </dialog>

modules.title: 28.2 Displaying the Dialog (show(), showModal())
modules.content: The show() method displays the dialog as non-modal. The showModal() method displays it modally, blocking interaction with content outside the dialog and supporting the **Esc** key to close it.
modules.sample: // Modal (preferred for popups): document.getElementById('my-dialog').showModal();

modules.title: 28.3 Closing the Dialog (close() and method='dialog')
modules.content: A dialog can be closed programmatically using close(), or declaratively by adding a <form> inside the dialog with a button or input having the method="dialog" attribute.
modules.sample: <form method="dialog"> <button>Close</button> </form>

modules.title: 28.4 Styling the Dialog Backdrop (::backdrop)
modules.content: When a dialog is shown modally (via showModal()), the browser automatically creates an opaque overlay behind it. This overlay can be styled using the CSS pseudoelement ::backdrop, commonly used to set a semi-transparent black background.
modules.sample: dialog::backdrop { background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5); }

modules.title: 28.5 The **<portal>** Element (Draft/Conceptual)
modules.content: The <portal> element is a proposed/experimental element that allows embedding another web page within a page, similar to an iframe, but with the ability to navigate into the embedded content. It's intended to enhance navigation transitions.
modules.sample: <portal src="/next-page.html"></portal> portal.addEventListener('click', () => portal.activate());

modules.title: 28.6 The **<datalist>** Element (Review)
modules.content: Review: The <datalist> element, covered in Intermediate HTML, is still an advanced UX feature that provides a list of suggested, editable options for an <input>. It is key to user-friendly forms.
modules.sample: <input list="browsers" /> <datalist id="browsers"> <option value="Chrome"> </datalist>

modules.title: 28.7 The **enterkeyhint** Attribute
modules.content: The enterkeyhint attribute provides a hint to mobile browsers about what the 'Enter' key on the virtual keyboard should display (e.g., 'go', 'next', 'done', 'send'). This improves the mobile form submission experience.
modules.sample: <input type="text" enterkeyhint="next" /> <input type="text" enterkeyhint="done" />

modules.title: 28.8 The **<details>** and **<summary>** Elements (Review)
modules.content: Review: The <details> and <summary> tags provide a native, accessible disclosure widget for creating collapsible sections (like accordions or FAQs) without requiring JavaScript or complex ARIA roles.
modules.sample: <details> <summary>Click to expand</summary> <p>The hidden content.</p> </details>

modules.title: 28.9 Form Validation Messages (setCustomValidity)
modules.content: You can override the browser's default form validation messages using JavaScript's setCustomValidity(message) method. If the message is a non-empty string, the field is considered invalid; an empty string makes it valid.
modules.sample: let input = document.getElementById('pword'); if (input.value !== confirm.value) { input.setCustomValidity('Passwords do not match.'); } else { input.setCustomValidity(''); }

modules.title: 28.10 CSS **:modal** Pseudoclass
modules.content: The CSS pseudoclass :modal matches any element that is currently in a modal state (e.g., a <dialog> element shown via showModal()). This allows for conditional styling when the element is active.
modules.sample: dialog:modal { border: 2px solid #007bff; box-shadow: 0 0 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5); }

modules.title: Did You Know? Default <dialog> State
modules.content: By default, a <dialog> element is hidden and uses display: none. When displayed with show() or showModal(), it reverts to display: block, but without the open attribute it will not display.

modules.title: Did You Know? The **formnovalidate** Attribute
modules.content: The boolean formnovalidate attribute can be placed on a submit button to temporarily override all the HTML5 validation (e.g., required, pattern) defined on the form and its inputs, forcing submission regardless of invalid data.
